citeinfo.title: Combined wildfire datasets for the United States and certain territories, 1800s-Present (combined wildland fire polygons)

descript.abstract: First, we would like to thank the wildland fire advisory group. Their wisdom and guidance helped us build the dataset as it currently exists. Currently, there are multiple, freely available fire datasets that identify wildfire and prescribed fire burned areas across the United States. However, these datasets are all limited in some way. Their time periods could cover only a couple of decades or they may have stopped collecting data many years ago. Their spatial footprints may be limited to a specific geographic area or agency. Their attribute data may be limited to nothing more than a polygon and a year. None of the existing datasets provides a comprehensive picture of fires that have burned throughout the last few centuries. Our dataset uses these existing layers and utilizes a series of both manual processes and ArcGIS Python (arcpy) scripts to merge these existing datasets into a single dataset that encompasses the known wildfires and prescribed fires within the United States and certain territories. Forty different fire layers were utilized in this dataset. First, these datasets were ranked by order of observed quality (Tiers). The datasets were given a common set of attribute fields and as many of these fields were populated as possible within each dataset. All fire layers were then merged together (the merged dataset) by their common attributes to created a merged dataset containing all fire polygons. Polygons were then processed in order of Tier (1-8) so that overlapping polygons in the same year and Tier were dissolved together. Overlapping polygons in subsequent Tiers were removed from the dataset. Attributes from the original datasets of all intersecting polygons in the same year across all Tiers were also merged so that all attributes from all Tiers were included, but only the polygons from the highest ranking Tier were dissolved to form the fire polygon. The resulting product (the combined dataset) has only one fire per year in a given area with one set of attributes. While it combines wildfire data from 40 wildfire layers and therefore has more complete information on wildfires than the datasets that went into it, this dataset has also has its own set of limitations. Please see the Data Quality attributes within the metadata record for additional information on this dataset's limitations. Overall, we believe this dataset is designed be to a comprehensive collection of fire boundaries within the United States and provides a more thorough and complete picture of fires across the United States when compared to the datasets that went into it.
descript.purpose: These datasets were created by combining 40 different, published wildland fire data sources. Each one of these data sources has a different spatial scale, spatial resolution, and time period for their particular wildland fire dataset. The purpose of these new datasets is to combine these disparate wildfire datasets, using a common set of attributes, into a single set of polygons with a single fire boundary for each fire. This dataset is intended to create a more comprehensive fire dataset than the existing datasets while eliminating duplication of fire polygons and attributes.
descript.supplinf: This data release includes the most up to date wildfire information through 2020. We anticipate, but cannot guarantee that this wildfire dataset will be updated yearly as new wildfire information becomes available.

idinfo.accconst: Public domain data from the U.S. Government are freely redistributable with proper metadata and source attribution. The U.S. Geological Survey requests to be acknowledged as originator of these data in future products or derivative research. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users need to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations. If there are any concerns, errors, or omissions in regard to this dataset, users should contact the data authors to gain additional information or to fix any existing errors in the data.

cntperp.cntorg: Forest and Rangeland Ecosystem Science Center

attracc.attraccr: These datasets were obtained from 40 different wildland fire datasets, each with their own limitations in accuracy in both time and space. We are relying on the original dataset attributes for accuracy. We cannot know, for example, whether the fire occurred in the year stated in the attributes or whether it was a different year. Whether derived by satellite imagery, created through the use of GPS points, or hand drawn on a topographic map, no wildfire perimeter is 100% accurate. In addition, not all fires were reported, especially older fires and smaller fires; thus fires reported in any year, especially those years before 1980, underestimate the actual number of fires. We intended to merge and dissolve different polygons that represent the same fire in different source datasets to create a single boundary for the wildfire. However, this dissolving process can result in the fire polygon with the least amount of detail contributing the most to the boundary of one fire. Instead of dissolving all fire polygons together regardless of dataset quality, our system broke the fires into 8 Tiers that were processed individually. By processing this data set in a tiered fashion (1-8) we hoped to improve accuracy of the polygons as each subsequent tier had fire polygons that intersected in space and fire year from the previous tiers removed before being processed. The goal was to improve the accuracy of the fire polygon. Whether this increases or decreases the accuracy of the fire boundary is unknown, because, as we stated before, no fire polygon is 100% accurate to begin with. The raster boundaries should be assumed to be the approximate area burned. These rasters represent the first year burned, most recent year burned, and the count of fires (all, wildfire, and prescribed) based on the data in the dataset itself. It is impossible know how many fires were missed, mis-attributed (a wildfire being labeled a prescribed fire or vice versa) or mapped improperly.

dataqual.logic: This dataset was designed to eliminate duplicate wildfire boundaries. All internal checks suggest we have merged the fire data correctly. Year ranges fall within expected ranges as do dates. We cannot say with 100% confidence that all boundaries within this dataset are properly attributed as wildfires or prescribed fires. We flagged fires where identical areas were burned in consecutive years. These could either be errors in the dataset or prescribed fire areas that are burned year after year. In the final, combined dataset, we flagged all fires that were circular in shape by calculating a circle-ness ratio and selecting all fires with a circle-ness ratio >=0.98 (values closer to 1 are more circular). Circular fires may be lightning strikes or fires where the true boundary was unknown and a user buffered a point. We also flagged fires where identical fire boundaries were detected in subsequent years. These likely represent the same fire and one dataset used an incorrect year. Users will have to have knowledge of their local area when determining whether this dataset accurately represents the area burned in the fire. Summary raster layers were checked to ensure that they match up to the polygon values to which they correspond. While we know the fire year of major fires is correct, there are thousands of smaller fires for which no record exists other than their inclusion in one of the original datasets. It is impossible for us to confirm all fire years in this dataset are accurate.
dataqual.complete:
We did our best to remove all wildfires without a Year Burned attribute, a year range, or an estimated year. We assumed that an area of land could not burn more than once in the same year. While extremely rare, burning twice in one year has been known to occur especially when a prescribed fire occurs in the spring and a wildfire burns through in the summer. However, even if an area did burn twice in the same year, for our purposes, we counted this as one burn. We assumed any fires that burned in the same year within 500m of each other were the same fire. This may not always be the case. While we would not lose the fire boundary itself, the fire attributes of these neighboring fires will be merged in to one record. Both of these assumptions will lower the count of actual fires, but should not affect the acreage. To be included in the combined dataset, the fire data had to have a list year that was not a range or an estimated year. Burned areas using carbon dating or other estimated years are included in the merged dataset, but were excluded from the combined dataset.
Wildfire_Notice Wildfire mapping prior to 1984 was inconsistent, infrequent, and done without the aid of more modern fire mapping methods (GPS and satellite imagery). Areas burned prior to 1984 in this dataset represent only a fraction of what actually burned. While areas burned on or after 1984 are much more accurate and complete, errors still can and do occur. This dataset represents the most complete set of digitized polygon fire data available to the public that we, the authors, were able to collect. It is not a complete collection of all wildfires burned during the time period it represents.
Prescribed_Burn_Notice Prescribed fire data in this dataset represents only a fraction of the area burned in prescribed burns across all years due to lack of reporting, particularly on private lands. The missing prescribed burn data becomes more pronounced further back in time, particularly in the southeastern U.S.; however, errors and omissions still occur through the most recent years in this dataset. This dataset represents the most complete set of digitized polygon fire data available to the public that we, the authors, were able to collect. It is not a complete collection of all prescribed burns burned during the time period it represents.

horizpa.horizpar: The horizontal accuracy is based on the inputs used to calculate this merged dataset. No fire perimeter is 100% accurate, however, and the fire perimeters in this dataset represent the approximate locations of the burned area.

procstep.procdesc: The original wildland fire datasets were downloaded from their original data sources. These feature classes were open and inspected. All fires that were clearly labeled as wildfires or prescribed fires were labeled as such. Remaining fires in wildfire datasets were labeled as "likely wildfire". Fires from the Monitoring Trends in Burn Severity Dataset marked as "Unknown" were labeled as "Unknown - Likely Wildfire" if a wildfire report existed for these fires. Otherwise, they were labeled as "Unknown - Likely Prescribed Fire". Additional fields were added to each dataset to create common fields across all original datasets (for a complete list of all the attributes see the "Entity and Attribute" section of this metadata record). These fields included Fire Source, Fire Tier, Fire Name, Fire Code, Fire Year, multiple fire dates, ignition source (human or natural), map method and notes. Available fields that matched these common fields were copied into the common field attributes using ArcGIS Field Calculator. For example, if the original dataset contained the attribute Name which was the name of the fire, these Name values were copied to the common Fire Name field. This allowed common fields to be matched across datasets regardless of what the original field attribute was. Fires with know fire years had their year value assigned to the Fire_Year field. All fires with carbon dating years, estimated years, fiscal years (where the calendar year could not be determined by the date), and year ranges were assigned to an estimated year field. All these datasets were then merged together into a single dataset to create the USGS_Wildland_Fire_Merged_Dataset and all data past 2020 was removed from the dataset. This original, merged dataset is included as one of the products in this download. It may have some uses, but has not been cleaned and should be used with care.
procstep.srcused: Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area 2020 Fires
Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area Historic Fires

procstep.procdesc: Once the data were merged, attribute information was brought into Tableau and a series of quality control steps were conducted in both Tableau and ArcGIS Pro in an attempt to improve data quality. Completed ignition, discover, controlled, contained, or fire out fields were used to fill in fire year fields where no year existed or only a fiscal year was listed. Many fires contained incorrect dates when the original dataset required a date and the date was unknown. For example, the date 1/1/1900 was used for many fires that did not occur in 1900. These incorrect dates that did not match the fire year were removed from the dataset. Finally, we noticed many prescribed fire datasets contained both a reported acreage and GIS acreage. We also noticed that the GIS acres were sometimes tens of thousands of times larger than the reported acres. These datasets contained GIS polygons that represented project areas of which only a small percentage was burned. Based on feedback from our team of wildfire experts we flagged any prescribed fires where the GIS and reported acres differed by more than 1000 acres wherever reported acres and GIS acres existed. Where reported acres did not exist, prescribed fires were included as there was no way to determine if the prescribed fire polygon was accurate. Fire "Tiers" were assigned to the various datasets based on feedback from our team of wildfire experts. These Tiers attempted to rank the fire datasets in order of quality. Fire Tiers were only assigned if the fire had a known fire year (estimated years, carbon dating years, missing years, and year ranges were excluded), GIS acres were greater than 0 (some features had null geometry), and prescribed fires were within 500. All fires there were assigned a Tier were exported and sorted by Tier, Fire Year (ascending), and GIS Acres (descending) to create a USGS_Wildland_Fire_Merged_Subset.

The US_Merged_Wildland_Fire_Subset was then run through a ArcGIS Pro Python (arcpy) script. This script selected each fire in order, one at a time. The first fire was selected (selection 1) and any fires within that Tier that overlapped in geographically and in the same year were also selected (selection 2). We assumed any fires that occurred within 500m of this fire were also fires from the same complex so we then selected any fires within 500m of selection 2. This 500m search distance selection was repeated within the Tier and year until no more fires were selected. The selected polygons (1 or more) were dissolved to make a single polygon that included the fire year as an attribute in a new dataset. The selected polygons were then deleted from the original Tier and any polygons that intersected the new dissolved polygon in space and year (additional duplicates in subsequent tiers) were also removed from the working dataset. This processed continued fire by fire until all fire polygons were processed and the USGS_Wildland_Fire_Combined_Dataset was created.

Once all polygons were processed, the attributes were added to each row. We selected each row in the USGS_Wildland_Fire_Combined_Dataset and went through each record one at a time. Using a copy of the US_Merged_Wildland_Fire_Subset we selected anything that intersected the selected record in both geographic location and year. We looped through each of these selected records and tallied the different attributes. For example if 10 records contained a polygon for the Soda wildfire the script looped through the fire names an assembled them in the Fire_Name field count. Using this example, let's say that 5 rows had a fire name of "Soda", 3 had "SODA", and two had "soda". The resulting Fire_Name attribute in the USGS_Wildland_Fire_Combined_Dataset for that row would appear like this: "Soda (5), SODA (3), soda (2)" where the parenthetical values represent the count of times that attribute appeared. This was done for all fields. All date fields, which were separate attributes in the US_Merged_Wildland_Fire_Subset, were combined into one date field with the specific type of date listed in the attributes. Within the fire team advising us, there was considerable concern about date quality. It was for this reason all the dates were combined into one field so as not to favor any date. The output of dates would look like this hypothetical example: Listed Wildfire Discovery Date(s): 2020-08-16 (2) | Listed Wildfire Controlled Date(s): 2020-11-17 (1), 2020-12-02 (1), 2020-11-16 (1) | Listed Wildfire Containment Date(s): 2020-11-14 (2), 2020-10-29 (1). As you can see from this example, the same date types are not always identical. This could be because the fire was actually two distinct fires or different dates were listed in different datasets for the same fire. In situations like this, the user is responsible for determining the true cause of this discrepancy.

After processing, the USGS_Wildland_Fire_Combined_Dataset underwent further testing and flagging of suspect rows. Some of the fires appear as near perfect circles. This could be from lightning strikes being counted as small fires or other small fires having a point buffered to the acreage of the fire size because no true polygon was created. A circle circle-ness index was calculated by using the following equation in Field Calculator "4*pi*(Shape_Area/(Shape_Length * Shape_Length))". As values approached 1, the shape became more circular. After a visual inspection of the polygons with values close to 1, we chose to create a "Circle_Flag" field and flag any shapes with a value greater than or equal to 0.98. We created two CSV tables included in this data release that highlight the number and percentage of these circular fire flags by year (Circular_Fire_Flag_Counts_by_Year.csv) and by state (Circular_Fire_Flag_Counts_by_State.csv).This does not mean that the flagged values are incorrect or that the unflagged values are correct. It is simply a way of highlighting some very circular polygons that may be incorrect. We included this measure of circle-ness as an additional field as well so that users could adjust the circle flag setting if needed. Our advisory group decided that any circular fires greater than 1 acre in size should be excluded from the summary raster dataset. Circular fire polygons are highly unlikely to represent the actual area burned. Where fire size was less than 1 acre, the advisory team determined that the risk of misassigning the burned area to the raster was minimal given the fire size. For any circular polygons greater than 1 acre, the risk of misassigning a burned area was too high and hence these were not included in the raster analysis. We included an Exclude_From_Summary_Rasters field to flag circular polygons greater than 1 acre in size so we could exclude them from the raster summaries.
We also ran a Tabulate Intersection of the fire dataset against itself to look at overlapping polygons. Tabulate Intersect measures the percent and amount of overlap from two different polygon datasets. By using the same dataset twice we were looking for any fires that overlapped our fire polygon in the same year or nearby years. Overlapping polygons should not occur within the same year and would be an error (we did not detect any). Polygons with near 100% overlap in consecutive years could be the same fire in different datasets with a year value that is correct in one and incorrect in another dataset. This can occur particularly with older fires. There is no way to identify the actual year or which one is correct, if one is in fact incorrect. Therefore, for any fires with >10% overlap within 1 -2 years of the focal fire, we included a flag warning field that indicates the percentage and acres overlap, the year the overlapping fire occurred, and the overlapping fires Assigned_USGS_ID. We included the full Tabulate Intersect as its own table (USGS_Wildland_Fires_Overlapping_Fire_Data) with all percentages and all years of overlap as one of the outputs as it may be of interest to some users. This dataset may be of particular interest to those who want to identify when and how much other fires have overlapped their fire boundary of interest. For example, if a user was interested in the wildfire USGS_Assigned_ID 82978 they could filter the USGS_Assigned_ID field by that value. This filter would return 13 rows in the overlap table. This indicates 13 different fires intersected fire 82978 at different points in time. Overlapping acres range from 1.8 to 1002 acres (0.14% to 81.5%) of the fire boundary and in years from 1996 to 2016 (22 to 2 years) before the fire of interest. Users can also see that only 3 of the other fires were wildfires while the other 10 are prescribed fires. In this way, users investigate the prior and subsequnt fire activity for each individual fire.
The final flag field highlighted records where attribute data indicated that the fire was both a wildfire and a prescribed fire. We created two CSV tables included in this data release that highlight the number and percentage of these wildfire and prescribed fire flags by year (Wildfire_and_Prescribed_Fire_Flag_Counts_By_Year.csv) and by state (Wildfire_and_Prescribed_Fire_Flag_Counts_By_State.csv). There are 3 main reasons this could occur. First, one of the entries may be in error. Prescribed fires may end up in a wildfire dataset or vice versa. Fires may also be given an incorrect fire designation in one or more datasets. Second, a wildfire may intentionally be assigned as a prescribed fire. This occurs when a wildfire burns through a planned prescribed burn area. Finally, it is possible, although rare, that a wildfire burns through an area later in the same year after a prescribed fire occurs in the spring. It is often difficult or impossible to determine the true answer and so the fields are simply flagged to warn the users that the fire may not actually be it's assigned fire type.

Once the QC checks on the final dataset were completed, summary rasters were generated from the polygon data. The fire polygons were turned into 30 meter rasters representing various summary counts: (a) count of all wildland fires that burned a pixel, (b) count of wildfires that burned a pixel, (c) the first year a wildfire burned a pixel, (d) the most recent year a wildfire burned a pixel, and (e) count of prescribed fires that burned a pixel. For full details on how these rasters were created see the raster metadata.

attr.attrdef: Unique identification for the polygon and it's attributes
The perceived quality of the fire feature as determined by the wildfire group with wildfires contained in Tiers 1-5 and prescribed fires contained in Tiers 6-8.

edom.edomvd: A Tier was not assigned to this fire either because the fire did not have a set calendar year or because the prescribed fire GIS acres were greater than 1000 acres compared to the reported acres.

attr.attrdef: The type of fire (prescribed or wild) either assigned to the feature based on the attributes or ascertained from the dataset itself. Qualifiers "Likely" and "Unknown" are used when the dataset did not specifically indicate the fire type.

edom.edomvd: The feature came from a wildfire dataset, but no attribute specifically indicated that this was a wildfire.
The feature came from a prescribed fire dataset and was labeled as a prescribed fire.
The MTBS dataset labeled this dataset as an unknown fire type. However, no wildfire report exists for this fire. Therefore, we are assuming this MTBS fire is a prescribed fire.
The MTBS dataset labeled this dataset as an unknown fire type. However, a wildfire report exists for this fire. Therefore, we are assuming this MTBS fire is a wildfire.
The feature came from a wildfire dataset and was clearly labeled as a wildfire.

attr.attrdef: The original data source of the individual feature. There are 40 original source datasets. See the source inputs for a full list of the individual datasets used
The calendar year when the dataset creators determined the fire occurred.

edom.edomvd: The calendar year the fire occurred could not be determined or was an estimate or range.

attr.attrdef: A categorical description of the year type listed in either the Fire_Calendar_Year field or the Estimated_Year_or_Range field.

edom.edomvd: Attributes indicate that year within the Fire_Calendar_Year field represents the calendar year when the fire occurred
Attributes indicate that the year within the Estimated_Year_or_Range field represents the year the prescribed fire contract was awarded. This may or may not be the year the prescribed fire occurred.
Attributes indicate that the year within the Estimated_Year_or_Range field was estimated using carbon dating.
Attributes indicate that the year within the Estimated_Year_or_Range field was an estimate and not necessarily the actual year of the fire.
Attributes indicate that the year within the Estimated_Year_or_Range field was the fiscal year of the fire and not necessarily the actual year of the fire.
Attributes indicate that the year within the Estimated_Year_or_Range field was the planned fiscal year of the prescribed fire and not necessarily the actual year of the fire.
Attributes indicate that the year within the Estimated_Year_or_Range field was likely an estimate. This was based on notes or other fields.
No year was provided in the attributes that would indicate the fire year, the true year cannot be estimated and is unknown
Attributes indicate that the year of the fire within the Estimated_Year_or_Range field was given as a range and was not the actual year.

attr.attrdef: If the fire year given was not the Actual Start Year, as indicated in the Fire_Year_Status column, the year estimate, year range, fiscal year, or carbon dating year was indicated here.

edom.edomvd: The actual year was recorded or no year was recorded.

attr.attrdef: The GIS calculated acres of the fire polygon calculated by using the Calculate Geometry tool in ArcGIS Pro.
The GIS calculated hectares of the fire polygon calculated by using the Calculate Geometry tool in ArcGIS Pro.
For prescribed fires, the user reported acres that were burned in the prescribed fire. These can be different than the GIS acres.

edom.edomvd: The fire was either a wildfire or no user reported acres were recorded for the prescribed fire.

attr.attrdef: When GIS acres exist, the value that exists when the GIS acres are subtracted from the reported acres. Positive values indicate that reported acres are greater than GIS acres. Negative values indicate that GIS acres are greater than reported acres.

edom.edomvd: No reported acres exist or the fire is a wildfire.

attr.attrdef: The name of the wildfire or prescribed fire. Null values were given the name "No Fire Name Provided".

For wildfires only, the 4 digit wildfire code assigned to the wildfire. Some wildfire datasets had codes longer than 4 digits and these were included as well if they were in the original code field. If no code was given or the fire was a prescribed fire, "No code provided" was entered.
The unique fire ID assigned to the fire by the original data source

edom.edomvd: No fire ID field existed in the original data source or the fire ID field was null for this fire.

attr.attrdef: The IRWIN ID assigned to the fire. Only recent wildfires have an IRWIN ID.

edom.edomvd: The fire did not have an IRWIN ID assigned.

attr.attrdef: The cause of the fire as indicated by the original data source.

edom.edomvd: No fire cause was listed.

attr.attrdef: A derived fire cause that was created for this dataset and based on the Fire_Cause field.

edom.edomvd: The fire was started by human caused activities.
The fire was started by natural phenomenon (usually lightning).
The cause of the fire was not determined or not listed.

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the wildfire first started.

edom.edomvd: No fire ignition date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the wildfire was first discovered.

edom.edomvd: No fire discovery date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the wildfire was first controlled.

edom.edomvd: No fire control date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the wildfire was discovered.

edom.edomvd: No fire containment date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the wildfire was contained.

edom.edomvd: No fire growth cessation date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the wildfire was declared out.

edom.edomvd: No fire out date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the prescribed fire was started.

edom.edomvd: No prescribed fire start date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the data source indicated that the prescribed fire was declared out.

edom.edomvd: No prescribed fire out date was recorded

attr.attrdef: Another date that might be important for the user.

edom.edomvd: No other fire date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The type of date recorded in the Other_Date field.

edom.edomvd: No other fire date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The date the fire polygon was uploaded into the original data source

edom.edomvd: No fire upload date was recorded

attr.attrdef: The original data source's description of how the fire perimeter was digitized.

edom.edomvd: No map digitization method was listed.

attr.attrdef: Any notes associated with the fire polygon as indicated by the original data source.

edom.edomvd: No notes field exists or no notes were indicated for this fire.

attr.attrdef: Notes created during the processing of this dataset if any field was changed from the original value and how and why it was modified.

edom.edomvd: No changes were made to this record.

attr.attrdef: Automatically calculated perimeter length in meters
Automatically calculated polygon area in square meters

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attr.attrdef: Unique identification for the polygon and it's attributes
Assigned unique identification for the polygon and it's attributes. Used to provide consistency if parts of the dataset are exported or the OBJECTID is otherwise changed.

Based on the fire polygon(s) used to create this fire feature what is the type assigned to this fire? If more than one type was assigned to a combined polygon, the assigned fire type was assigned in the following order of dominance: Wildfire, Likely Wildfire, Unknown - Likely Wildfire, Prescribed Fire, Unknown - Likely Prescribed Fire

edom.edomvd: At least one of the original polygons that went into the creation of this fire feature had a fire type equal to Wildfire
At least one of the original polygons that went into the creation of this fire feature had a fire type equal to Likely Wildfire and none of the polygons was equal to Wildfire.

At least one of the original polygons that went into the creation of this fire feature had a fire type equal to Unknown - Likely Wildfire and none of the polygons was equal to Wildfire or Likely Wildfire.

At least one of the original polygons that went into the creation of this fire feature had a fire type equal to Prescribed Fire and none of the polygons was equal to Wildfire, Likely Wildfire, or Unknown - Likely Wildfire.
Only polygons with a fire type of Unknown - Likely Prescribed Fire were recorded for this fire.

attr.attrdef: The calendar year when the dataset creators determined the fire occurred.
The tier from which the fire polygon was generated. One or more polygons within the tier could be combined to create the fire polygon.
All fire tiers that contributed attributes to the fire feature. A list of all tiers where a polygon intersects the current fire perimeter in space and time.
The GIS calculated acres of the fire polygon calculated by using the Calculate Geometry tool in ArcGIS Pro.
The GIS calculated hectares of the fire polygon calculated by using the Calculate Geometry tool in ArcGIS Pro.
All of the original source datasets that contributed to either the polygon or the attributes. Each dataset has the number of polygons contributed listed in parentheses after the dataset name.

Each fire type listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire type are in parentheses after the fire type.

Each fire name listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire name are in parentheses after the fire name.

Each fire code listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire code are in parentheses after the fire code.

Each fire type listed in the IDs from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire ID are in parentheses after the fire ID.

edom.edomvd: No fire IDs were found in any of the datasets that contributed to this polygon.

attr.attrdef: Each fire IRWIN ID listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire IRWIN ID are in parentheses after the fire IRWIN ID.

edom.edomvd: No IRWIN IDs were found in any of the datasets that contributed to this polygon.

attr.attrdef: Each fire date listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire date are in parentheses after the fire date.

edom.edomvd: No fire dates were found in any of the datasets that contributed to this polygon.

attr.attrdef: Each fire cause listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire cause are in parentheses after the fire cause.

edom.edomvd: No fire causes were found in any of the datasets that contributed to this polygon.

attr.attrdef: Each fire cause class listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire cause class are in parentheses after the fire cause class.

Each prescribed fire reported acres listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific reported acres are in parentheses after the reported acres.

edom.edomvd: There are no reported acres for wildfires, if null for prescribed fires, the prescribed fire did not have a reported acreage in any of the datasets that were used.

attr.attrdef: Each fire digitization method listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire digitization method are in parentheses after the fire digitization method.

edom.edomvd: No map digitization methods were found in any of the datasets that contributed to this polygon.

attr.attrdef: Each fire notes listed in the fires from the merged dataset that intersect this polygon in space and year. The number of features that contributed the specific fire notes are in parentheses after the fire note.

edom.edomvd: No fire notes were found in any of the datasets that contributed to this polygon.

attr.attrdef: Indicates that the attribute data were altered during the processing and a new attribute was indicated. It will also explain the rationale for the change. Each polygon that had an attribute changed will be listed along with a count, in parentheses indicating how many polygons had the change made to them.

edom.edomvd: No notes

attr.attrdef: A notice present in every field that indicates the quality of the wildfire data in this dataset.
A notice present in every field that indicates the quality of the prescribed burn data in this dataset.

A text flag field indicating that the attributes from the various sources indicate that the fire was both a wildfire and a prescribed fire. This could indicate an error in assigning the fire type, a misassignment of the fire type, or that there were actually two fires that occurred in this area in the same year, one a wildfire and one a prescribed burn.

edom.edomvd: The fire has only one fire type, wildfire or prescribed fire, associated with it.

attr.attrdef: An ArcGIS Tabulate Intersection Tool was used to identify areas that burned with >10% overlap of the current fire within 1 or 2 years of the current burn. Each fire that met that criteria was included in this attribute including it's ID, year burned, percent overlap, and acres.

edom.edomvd: No Data

attr.attrdef: A measure of a polygon's similarity to a true circle. calculated using the Shape_Length and Shape_Area fields. Circle-ness = 4*pi*(Shape_Area/(Shape_Length * Shape_Length)). As the number approaches 1, the polygon becomes more circular.

Any Circle circle-ness values >=0.98 are flagged with a 1. The remaining values are null. 1 indicates that the polygon is very circle-like and is likely incorrect. However, other values that are not flagged may still be quite circular and incorrect.

edom.edomvd: The circle circle-ness is <0.98 and the polygon has not been flagged as being very circular.
The circle circle-ness is >=0.98 and the polygon has been flagged as being very circular.

attr.attrdef: Some fires in this dataset appear to be buffered circles. These were kept in the dataset to show location and approximate area. However a decision was made to exclude circular fires larger than 1 acre in size from the summary raster calculations. This field indicates whether the fire was excluded from ('Yes') or included in ('No') the summary raster calculations.

edom.edomvd: This is a non-circular fire and was included in the raster summary datasets
This is a circular fire larger than 1 acre in size and was excluded from the raster summary datasets

attr.attrdef: Automatically calculated perimeter length in meters
Automatically calculated polygon area in square meters

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attr.attrdef: Unique identification for the table row

A unique ID assigned by the USGS creators of the dataset to the focal fire. Used to identify the unique fire polygon in the original dataset. This is used instead of OBJECTID because OBJECTIDs can change if the dataset is manipulated. This field should not be edited or altered.
The fire type assigned to the focal fire boundary during the creation of the dataset

edom.edomvd: The fire was likely a wildfire but there is no way to confirm this.
The fire is a confirmed wildfire based on the available attributes.
The fire is a confirmed prescribed fire based on the available attributes.
This polygon came from MTBS and was labeled "Unknown". However, research done by Karen Short indicates that the fire is likely a wildfire.
This polygon came from MTBS and was labeled "Unknown". However, research done by Karen Short indicates that the fire is likely a prescribed fire.

attr.attrdef: The fire year assigned to the focal fire boundary during the creation of the dataset
The acres the focal and overlapping fire overlap with each other.
The percentage the focal fire is overlapped by the overlapping fire.

A unique ID assigned by the USGS creators of the dataset to the overlapping fire. Used to identify the unique fire polygon in the original dataset. This is used instead of OBJECTID because OBJECTIDs can change if the dataset is manipulated. This field should not be edited or altered.
The fire type assigned to the overlapping fire boundary during the creation of the dataset

edom.edomvd: The fire was likely a wildfire but there is no way to confirm this.
The fire is a confirmed prescribed fire based on the available attributes.
The fire is a confirmed wildfire based on the available attributes.
This polygon came from MTBS and was labeled "Unknown". However, research done by Karen Short indicates that the fire is likely a wildfire.
This polygon came from MTBS and was labeled "Unknown". However, research done by Karen Short indicates that the fire is likely a prescribed fire.

attr.attrdef: The fire year assigned to the overlapping fire boundary during the creation of the dataset

The number of years before or after the focal fire the overlapping fire occurred. Negative values indicate the overlapping fire occurred before the focal fire. Positive values indicate the overlapping fire occurred after the focal fire.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attr.attrdef: The year in which the fires occurred
Count of the total number of fire polygons that occurred in that year.
The circle-ness value at which a fire was considered circular in the dataset. For the 2021 release that value was >=0.98
The number of fires in the Fire Year that were flagged as being very circular
The proportion of fires (0 to 1) in a given year that were flagged as being very circular.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attr.attrdef: The state in which the fires occurred. If a fire crossed state lines it was counted in both states
The full text name of the state.
Count of the total number of fire polygons that occurred in that state.
The circle-ness value at which a fire was considered circular in the dataset. For the 2021 release that value was >=0.98
The number of fires in the state that were flagged as being very circular
The proportion of fires (0 to 1) in a given state that were flagged as being very circular.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attr.attrdef: The year in which the fires occurred
Count of the total number of fire polygons that occurred in that year.

attr.attrlabl: Count Wildfire and Prescribed Fire Flag
attr.attrdef: The number of fires in the Fire Year that were flagged as being both a wildfire and a prescribed fire
The proportion of fires (0 to 1) in a given year that were flagged as being both a wildfire and a prescribed fire

enttyp.enttypd: Comma Separated Value (CSV) file containing data.

attr.attrdef: The state in which the fires occurred. If a fire crossed state lines it was counted in both states
The full text name of the state.
Count of the total number of fire polygons that occurred in that state.

attr.attrlabl: Count Wildfire and Prescribed Fire Flag
attr.attrdef: The number of fires in the state that were flagged as being both a wildfire and a prescribed fire
The proportion of fires (0 to 1) in a given state that were flagged as being both a wildfire and a prescribed fire

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, product, or firm names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.

cntperp.cntorg: Forest and Rangeland Ecosystem Science Center

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Biological Data Profile of the Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
